review.title: A Logical Characterization of Constraint-Based Causal Discovery
review.abstract: We present a novel approach to constraint-based causal discovery, that takes the form of straightforward logical inference, applied to a list of simple, logical statements about causal relations that are derived directly from observed (in)dependencies. It is both sound and complete, in the sense that all invariant features of the corresponding partial ancestral graph (PAG) are identified, even in the presence of latent variables and selection bias. The approach shows that every identifiable causal relation corresponds to one of just two fundamental forms. More importantly, as the basic building blocks of the method do not rely on the detailed (graphical) structure of the corresponding PAG, it opens up a range of new opportunities, including more robust inference, detailed accountability, and application to large models.

sections.text: We present a novel approach to limitation-based causal discovery, which is applied in the form of a simple logical conclusion to a list of simple, logical statements about causal relationships derived directly from observed (non) dependencies. It is both solid and complete, as all invariant features of the corresponding partial ancestor graph (PAG) are identified, even with latent variables and selection bias. The approach shows that any identifiable causal relationship corresponds to one of only two basic forms. More importantly, since the basic building blocks of the method are not based on the detailed (graphical) structure of the corresponding PAG, it opens up a range of new possibilities, including more robust conclusions, detailed accountability, and application to large models.

sections.heading: 2.3 Augmented FCI algorithm
sections.text: The famous Fast Causal Inference (FCI) algorithm (Spirtes et al., 2000) was one of the first algorithms to be able to derive causal relationships from conditional independence statements in the large sample boundary, even in the presence of latent and selective variables. It consists of an efficient search for conditional independence between each pair of variables to identify the skeleton of the underlying causal MAG, followed by an orientation stage to identify invariant tail and arrow markers. It was shown to be in the large sample boundary (Spirtes et al., 1999), although it is not yet complete. Ali et al. (2005) proved that the seven graphic orientation rules applied by FCI are sufficient to identify all invariant arrowheads in the equivalence class.

sections.heading: 4 A logical characterization of causal information
sections.text: In this section we show that the combination of the logical statements derived directly from observed / inferred conditional (in) dependencies via lemmas 3 and 4, together with the three inference rules in sentence 1, is sufficient to obtain all invariant orientations (tails and arrowheads) in the PAG. We do this by assigning each orientation rule to specific instances of the lemmas and information already inferred, taking advantage of the well-known completeness of the advanced FCI algorithm.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion and conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have developed a new approach that is based on constraints and allows for causal discoveries: the observed minimal (in) dependencies are transformed into logical statements about causal relationships, and these statements are then combined with basic properties of causality. It leads to a remarkably simple characterization in which all identifiable causal relationships take the form of (inferred) minimal conditional independence, with both alternatives leading to the same conclusion. The resulting logical causal inference has been used in an efficient algorithm that is the first alternative to the augmented FCI algorithms, which are both solid and complete. LoCI algorithms are strikingly simpler than their counterpart in Section 2.3. Although they are not necessarily faster than the totality of complexity we dominate, the fact is that implementation is very simple and elegant.
